newsitem.title: UK: FOCUS - Rolls falls, div unchanged after loss.
newsitem.headline: FOCUS - Rolls falls, div unchanged after loss.

text.p: Shares in Rolls-Royce fell 2.6 percent on Thursday as the aircraft engine maker disappointed with an unchanged interim dividend following a first-half loss due to one-off charges.
The loss and the charges, which were related to Rolls-Royce's withdrawal from the loss-making large steam power generation business, were as expected.
But analysts were disheartened that the dividend was left at two pence per share, prompting them to cut their full-year dividend forecasts.

Rolls-Royce earlier reported a first-half loss of 169 million pounds ($263.6 million) compared with a 70 million pound profit a year ago, due to exceptional charges of 248 million to cover withdrawal from large steam power generation.
The company said the current provisions had prevented it to raise the pay-out.
Rolls-Royce shares dropped six pence to 225-1/2, but industry watchers see little further downward potential in the short-term ahead of next week's Farnborough airshow.
"We'd expect to see, particularly over Farnborough, some good order announcements which might help the shares in the short-term," said analyst Nick Cunningham at broker BZW.

But an order worth up to $450 million from Egypt's Kato Group to power a batch of Russian-built aircraft failed to lift sentiment on Thursday. "The dividend is clearly disappointing," said analyst Paul Pickford.
Rolls-Royce, however, was cautiously upbeat about future prospects as the civil aircraft market was picking up and spares sales were rising.
"The immediate outlook is steady and, with the introduction of new products over the next few years, the company is confident of achieving future growth," it said.
First-half results showed the underlying strength of its aerospace group, the company added.

"Our decision to withdraw from large steam power generation recognises the need to focus upon those businesses where we have established or can establish leading market positions," chairman Sir Ralph Robins said.
The main growth for Rolls-Royce is in civil aircraft engine orders, but Robins said it is too early yet to make firm predictions on prospects in this market segment.
"The airlines have had many years of lossmaking and now they are in the second year of making profits, so I am slightly cautious how long this improvement continues," he told Reuters.
"But there is no doubt there is much more activity than there was last year," Robins added, while speaking on engine orders for civil aircraft in the first-half of 1996.
The company recently secured orders for planes to be used by a host of Asian flag carriers such as Malaysia Airlines, Thai Airways International and Cathay Pacific.
Rolls-Royce's sales from continuing operations rose to 1.77 billion pounds from 1.49 billion pound.
"There is a lot of activity in the civil business. We are seeing growth everywhere," Robins said. "We are negotiating with airlines throughout the world for our whole range of products."
Robins said spares orders for engines had continued to increase in the first-half as airlines have begun to re-stock after a long period in which they ran down their stocks.
"We may be seeing around 10 percent (spares order growth)," he said.
